data.title: 145. The OEM conundrum — Rhishi Pethe
data.meta_description: Will drone based applications threaten ground based application equipment business?
data.text:
“Software is Feeding the World” is a weekly newsletter about technology trends for Food/AgTech leaders.

I (Rhishi Pethe) am a techno-optimist. I believe technology will play a role to bend the arc of future food and agriculture systems to be more sustainable.

If this email was forwarded to you, you can subscribe and read past editions by clicking on Subscribe

Greetings from Las Trampas Regional Park in the San Francisco Bay Area!

Paradigm Shifts

DuPont was a chemical company for most of its existence, till they acquired Pioneer Seeds in the 1990s and then it has ultimately turned into an agrochemical giant Corteva with a chemical and seed portfolio. (report from 1999)

Monsanto was a chemical company for most of its existence, till they got into biotechnology and then they became a seed company, and are now Bayer Crop Science with a chemical and seed portfolio.

Seed and chemical businesses have a number of synergies. For example, seed companies can develop seeds that are resistant to certain pests and diseases, and chemical companies can develop pesticides and herbicides that are specifically designed for those seeds. This can lead to better crop yields and higher profits for farmers.

The combination of seed and chemical business was a paradigm shift in how inputs were sold, developed together, and purchased by farmers.

Paradigm shifts can present an opportunity to strengthen an incumbent's business (seed and chemicals being an example) or it can put incumbents at significant risks of losing a large chunk of their business.

Paradigm shifts often happen due to a technology shift, business model change, or regulatory changes.

There are many examples in business in the last few decades - GMO crops, SaaS models, mobile computing, cloud computing, iPhone etc.

If you are not a Game of Thrones fan, you can skip this paragraph, but the key takeaway of the paragraph is: paradigm shifts can put incumbents at significant risk.

In season 2, episode 7 of Game of Thrones, Tywin Lannister and Arya Stark talk about Harrenhal. (These are some of the best scenes from the series.)

Tywin says the Castle of Harrenhal was designed to hold out against a land army of a million men, but Aegon rode dragons and destroyed the impregnable castle by attacking it through the air.

Aegon shifted the paradigm of warfare, and made the incumbent castle useless.

Potential paradigm shifts on the horizon (or maybe far out) in agriculture

There are a couple of future potential paradigm shifts in agriculture - if, how, and when they will happen is anybody’s guess.

Here are some examples:

Will precision application of inputs like herbicides, pesticides, and nutrition inputs seriously jeopardize the business of input companies, though it might be great for farmers and the environment? (See edition 128, edition 130, etc.)

Will the paradigm of “bigger is better” be jeopardized by an “Android” type of model for agriculture equipment, and be great for the environment? (See edition 132 (The Dominion of Incumbents), edition 89 (Android Strategy for Agriculture Equipment), and in many other editions)

Will the advances in drone technology coupled with distribution jeopardize the business of agriculture equipment companies? (See edition 137 etc.)

Let us look at the last one in a bit more detail

On the ground or through the air?

Traditionally within agriculture, ground based equipment has been used (where it is available, applicable, and affordable), for most farm activities in row crops like tillage, planting/seeding, nutrition and crop protection applications, harvesting etc.

The situation is a bit different in specialty crops, where many of the activities are done by humans. In many smallholder context, equipment is not available or affordable.

There is a need to advance precision agriculture, human augmentation, and automation in all cropping systems to address high input costs, challenges with availability of labor, and sustainability and regulatory challenges.

There are some new technologies which are becoming more viable over the last few years, which could potentially change the paradigm of doing most farming operations using ground based equipment.

This is especially true in the realm of precision agriculture.

In the seminal book, “Thinking in Systems - A Primer”, Donella H Meadows talks about how one can create change in systems. (This book should be required reading for everyone).

She describes 12 leverage points, and places to intervene in a system in order of effectiveness. Number 2 on her list is paradigm changes.

Paradigms are the sources of systems. From them, from shared social agreements about the nature of reality, come system goals and information flows, feedbacks, stocks, flows, and everything else about systems.

If you are a ground based equipment manufacturer (an OEM), one way to think about the different technologies which are available today, and which are on the horizon is to understand the applicability of these technologies across different cropping systems and operations.

The table below shows an example of one such representation. The table is not supposed to be comprehensive, and the company names I have mentioned in the table are the ones I know of.

There are many other dimensions to this table like region of the world, practices in different cropping systems, economic environment, farmer dynamics, regulation etc., but only two dimensions can be shown in a flat table.

The question for an existing incumbent is as to which squares on this chart they should play in to get the right share of their customer’s investment on these applications and the necessary equipment needed to support those activities.

For startups, it is better to start by focusing on just one square (actually a very small part of a given square), find product market fit, expand within the same square, before moving on to another square.

What should incumbents do?

Incumbents have to tackle similar questions. Incumbents have more tools at their disposal to play in different squares.

Incumbents could do M&A transactions (for e.g. Deere acquiring Blueriver), joint ventures (for e.g., AGCO and Trimble joint venture), investments through their corporate VC arms (for e.g. Leaps by Bayer investment in Rantizo or Syngenta Ventures investment in Greeneye), establish close relationships through accelerator programs (Deere with Burro), or use some other tools.

The level of investment in terms of time, resources, and money is different in each of these tools, but it gives a closer look inside a square to an entity like Deere.

If we take the example of Deere, and highlight the squares where they are playing in through one of the above mentioned tools, the chart looks something like this.

As you can see from the chart, Deere is making investments in many squares across different cropping systems (row, specialty, tree), and different technology form factors (new equipment, retrofit, or new robots).

Deere does operate in the smallholder space, but my understanding is that their involvement is limited.

As can be seen from the chart, Deere does not participate in irrigation capabilities (it does have some software and mapping products), or any aerial applications in any significant way.

Deere also does not seem to have used any tools at its disposal in the specialty retrofit market outside of permanent tree crops through their acquisition of SmartApply.

It is interesting to see that ground based technology providers do not cross over to aerial technology and vice versa.

It is not surprising, given the skills, resources, and experience required to build ground based moving equipment is different from a pivot or irrigation system which is stationary, and is very different from building aerial technology with planes and drones.

But how should a Deere (or another large OEM) react, if the drone based application services become competitive with ground based services in terms of the economics, and the effectiveness of the technology?

Jobs-to-be-done

If we look at it from a jobs-to-be-done framework, as a grower I want to have crop protection in an economical and timely fashion throughout the year.

Yes, there are farmers who like to ride their equipment. But most farmers want effective crop protection, and want to use any and all applicable tools at their disposal (it has to be economical, easy, and effective though).

As my friend Shane Thomas covered in his writeup about Rantizo’s recent fundraise, ground based rigs have many shortcomings.

However, there are shortcomings of ground rigs— they include:

Expensive to purchase and operate

Cause crop trample and soil compaction

Large leading to challenges in tighter or smaller field areas (eg: around power lines or terraced land)

Lose efficiency for spot spray applications (eg: nutrient deficiency management)

Cannot be used when soil is too wet

I will add one more to the list.

Ground rigs are difficult to transport and expensive to transport, whereas a swarm of drones could be folded up and loaded onto a semi and be moved to a different spot.

Drones are a very small percentage of the overall application business, and there are still some roadblocks to adoption.

Distribution network

Coverage & efficiency of drone applications

Regulations which restrict usage of drones beyond a certain minimum set of requirements.

Trained drone operators

Technology and support infrastructure and tools

Charging infrastructure

Safety issues

If some of these roadblocks are knocked down, it could potentially create an orthogonal distribution and service network, compared to the existing ground based equipment distribution and service network.

Today’s ground based sprayers provide high efficiency and capacity, but cannot operate in fields during certain conditions. For example,

The wet weather during months of May and June across much of the southeastern US also made most fields inaccessible with ground application equipment, hence limiting the timely pesticide applications for most growers.

With improvements in battery life, changes in regulations, and building of a service/orchestration network (as highlighted by Shane), drone based applications could start taking away some activities from ground based rigs.

Drones can be a good option (assuming economic & operational viability, and effectiveness) in certain challenging conditions as described above.

Today ground based equipment manufacturers provide products which work under certain conditions of region, crop type, time of year, environmental conditions etc.

A service provider or a retailer can fill in the gaps as needed, if it makes sense.

For example, an Ag Retailer can provide spraying services to a farmer using a ground based sprayer. If a drone is required to spray due to certain conditions, a drone service provider or a retailer can fill the gap for the grower from a jobs-to-be-done framework standpoint.

Even if many of the technology, regulatory, and operational challenges are solved, incumbents have such a stranglehold on distribution, it is extremely challenging for a startup to try to go around it, unless you are taking a different approach.

I have quoted Alex Rampell (VC at a16z) many times in this newsletter before,

The battle between every startup and incumbent comes down to whether the startup gets distribution before the incumbent gets innovation.

So is it even possible for a startup to get to distribution before an incumbent gets to innovation?

It is very much possible, if the incumbent thinks that a particular innovation is not a square they want to play in. (Refer to the chart by me before)

Which square do you want to play in?

As we have seen so far, OEM incumbents do not want to play in the drone or aerial application business. (so far). Can these new age start ups try to spin up their own distribution network?

For example, most of the new management team at Rantizo came from Skyward, a drone management company owned by Verizon (which was surprisingly shutdown last year). (Highlights by me)

​The company’s drone software platform helped customers manage their entire drone workflow, including training crews, planning missions, accessing controlled airspace and more.

Since opening the new business unit, Verizon seems to have pivoted more and more towards AMRs. “The Verizon Robotics Group enables

enterprise customers to efficiently adopt and scale Autonomous Mobile Robots (AMR) to improve productivity, deliver faster time to insight, and reduce costs through automation and 5G.

​The video above highlights 5G connectivity (given it is a Verizon ad), but the general principles will hold for agriculture with the use of AMRs (technical term for drones, though they are not fully autonomous yet.)

Some of these drone companies are playing in squares, which existing incumbents have shown no inclination to do so, and are trying to ramp up an orthogonal support and distribution network.

Just like we saw with seed & chemical business, will ground-based agriculture equipment manufacturers acquire drone companies and service providers?

Are the new age drone companies targets for incumbents, or if some of the distribution etc. challenges are solved, will they become competitors to OEMs?

Is the future already here?

But how can paradigms change or shift to create a different future?

Thomas Kuhn, who wrote the fantastic book about the great paradigm shifts in science, “The Structure of Scientific Revolutions” said the following about changing paradigms.

You keep pointing at the anomalies and failures in the old paradigm. You keep speaking and acting, loudly and with assurance, from the new one. You insert people with the new paradigm in places of public visibility and power. You don’t waste time with reactionaries; rather, you work with active change agents and with the vast middle ground of people who are open-minded.

If one thinks about the drone business, as the great science fiction author William Gibson said,

The future is already here - it is just not evenly distributed.

What do you think?

If you like “Software is feeding the world”, please share with a friend.

If you don’t mind answering 3 questions anonymously (2 are optional), I would love to get your feedback.

The views expressed in this newsletter are my personal opinions.
